# Chernoff Bounds
## Theorem (Chernoff Bound for Gaussians)
Let \(X_i \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) be independent random variables. Let \(X := \sum_i X_i\). $$\Pr(X/n - \mu \geq t) \leq e^{-\frac{nt^2}{2\sigma^2}}$$

Proof.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pr(X/n - \mu \geq t) = & \Pr(e^{\lambda(X - n\mu)} \geq e^{n\lambda t})\\
\leq & \inf_{\lambda \geq 0} e^{-n\lambda t} E\left[e^{\lambda(X - n\mu)}\right]\\
= & \inf_{\lambda \geq 0} e^{-n\lambda t} \prod_iE\left[e^{\lambda(X_i - \mu)}\right]\\
= & \inf_{\lambda \geq 0} e^{-n\lambda t+ \frac{n\sigma^2\lambda^2}{2}}, \qquad \text{since } E\left[e^{\lambda X_i}\right] = e^{\lambda\mu + \frac{\sigma^2\lambda^2}{2}}.\\
= & e^{-\frac{nt^2}{2\sigma^2}}, \qquad \text{since } \lambda = \frac{t}{\sigma^2} \text{ minimizes this}.\\
\end{aligned}
$$

# Sub-Gaussian Random Variables

Definition.
\(X\) is sub-gaussian with parameter \(\sigma^2\) if, for all \(\lambda \in \mathbb{R}\),
$$\log M_{X-\mu}(\lambda) \leq \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2}, \text{ where } M_{X-\mu}(\lambda) = E\left[e^{\lambda(X-\mu)}\right].$$
